review.title: Exact Inference for Relational Graphical Models with Interpreted Functions: Lifted Probabilistic Inference Modulo Theories
review.abstract: Probabilistic Inference Modulo Theories (PIMT) is a recent framework that expands exact inference on graphical models to use richer languages that include arithmetic, equalities, and inequalities on both integers and real numbers. In this paper, we expand PIMT to a lifted version that also processes random functions and relations. This enhancement is achieved by adapting Inversion, a method from Lifted First-Order Probabilistic Inference literature, to also be modulo theories. This results in the first algorithm for exact probabilistic inference that efficiently and simultaneously exploits random relations and functions, arithmetic, equalities and inequalities.

sections.heading: 3.6 A Proof-of-concept Experiment
sections.text: Since SEMT and inversion modulo theories are sophisticated symbolic algorithms, two immediate questions are whether they can be implemented effectively and how they can be compared with simpler alternatives such as sampling. As a proof-of-concept test, we used our implementation of SEMT to calculate Example 3.4, using two alternatives: one where the sum product is simplified by inversion modulo theories, and another where sum and product are calculated by sampling. As expected, the inversion modulo theories far exceed the sample in this example by calculating the exact response (82590) in less than 300 ms, while the sample takes 10 minutes and 10,000 samples per quantifier to be within an order of magnitude of the exact answer, and 17 minutes to be within a 10% error.

sections.heading: 4 RELATED WORK AND CONCLUSION
sections.text: As mentioned in the introduction, LPIMT generalizes work in upscale inference, probabilistic inference, and the satisfaction of modular theories. It also refers to probabilistic programs (PP) (Goodman et al., 2012; Milch et al., 2005), a class of high-level representations that use interpreted and uninterpreted functions. Currently, the dominant inference method in PPs is sampling, whose convergence depends on the size of the grounded model, that is, on the size of the domain. LPIMT can be applied to some fragments of the PPs and is an exact inference alternative that avoids iteration across the domain.
